paragraphs.text: Diversity among police officers is key, but it won't solve the problems with policing.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: In Ferguson, Missouri, 50 of the 53 police officers are white in a city that is two-thirds African American
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: In Connecticut's state capital, Hartford, 66% of the police department is white
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: only 16% of the residents are
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: And these are just two examples: despite progress over the past 50 years, many police departments remain predominantly white in cities and towns
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: where the majority of the population is nonwhite
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: There are some important exceptions to the disparity pattern
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Several big city police departments are majority-black or majority-Hispanic (Atlanta, Birmingham, Detroit, Washington, Miami, Santa Fe and El Paso, for instance)
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: while others (such as Chicago) are so diverse that no single group comprises the majority
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Yet for many other cities, the gap between the complexion of the police department and the local population is huge
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Why does this matter?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Do police officers of different racial and ethnic backgrounds act differently while on the job?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Do they have different kinds of relationships with minority communities?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Aren't all officers trained to do their jobs similarly and to treat all civilians the same regardless of race?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Research shows that, in general in the US, there is not a strong correlation, let alone a causal relationship, between an officer's race and how officers treat members of the public when they respond to calls from civilians or stop and question them on the streets Statistics
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: are, of course, not predictive of individual behavior
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: studies of specific departments or communities vary
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A 2004 study in Indianapolis (Indiana) and St  Petersburg (Florida) by Ivan Sun and Brian Payne, for example, found that black officers were more likely than white officers working in black neighborhoods to provide information, referrals to other agencies, and to treat residents respectfully
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: although the black officers were also more likely to use physical force against citizens in conflict situations
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: again, most studies find similarities overall in police behavior irrespective of officers' racial background
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Shared training in the academy, as well as on-the-job socialization by fellow officers, results in more similarities than differences among officers when it comes to their policing activities, including similarities in how officers of all races treat white versus non-white citizens
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So we should not view racial diversification on the force as a panacea for improving police treatment of minorities
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: instead if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: minority officers adopt majority attitudes about those they serve and protect
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it might hardly help at all
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A 2008 study in Baltimore, Maryland by Peter Moskos documented precisely this shared mentality among both white and black officers
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: But it can pay major dividends in other ways
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In one poll of 1,791 Americans that I and a colleague conducted for our book, Race and Policing in America, more than 70% of blacks, Hispanics and whites in the United States believed that a city's police department should have a similar racial composition to the city
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: The same study found that very few blacks and Hispanics (only 5%) want most officers who work in their neighborhoods to be exclusively of the same race as the residents
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: instead most people prefer to see racially- mixed teams of officers patrolling their streets
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Importantly, such diversity can help to build trust and confidence in the police
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the more a police department reflects the composition of the local population, the higher the department's reputation among residents
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which can provide a foundation to build further trust, coupled with other needed reforms
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It also helps, in majority-black or majority-Hispanic cities, if the chief of police comes from that community as well because, as the public face of the department, he or she can allay suspicions
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: when controversial incidents occur in a way that white police chiefs may not be able to do
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A diverse police force can also help to decrease the sense that individuals are being stopped and questioned solely because of their race
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This clearly applies when the officers and citizens are of the same race
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: even encounters between white officers and minority citizens may be perceived as less racialized when the department has a critical mass of minority officers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A representative police force can, in other words, have symbolic benefits that enhance the overall status of a police department and also reduce the perception that actions, such as stops or searches, are based on racial profiling
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Most police chiefs realize the advantages of a department that represents the local community
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there are big challenges in recruiting more minority officers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Many Hispanics and African Americans are reluctant to consider a career in law enforcement - not surprising, given the history of policing in America coupled with more recent events
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Highly-publicized incidents like the killing of Michael Brown in Ferguson and Eric Garner in New York only make it more difficult for police departments to recruit minority officers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Recruiters can have some success, however, if they broaden their outreach efforts to include churches and community centers - and if there are pre- existing positive relationships between the police and residents in those minority neighborhoods where community policing has already taken root
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which can be built on
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Although troubled interactions between minorities and police garner most of the headlines, there are neighborhoods in American cities where working-class and middle-class black and Hispanic residents - including youths - have better relationships with the authorities than on average, as I found in a study of Washington DC neighborhoods
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: It is in these communities that the police can enhance their recruitment efforts and achieve at least some success
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Racial diversification is one crucial ingredient in a larger program of reform that is required to improve police departments throughout the country
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A representative police force is not a panacea
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: - but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it is a positive reform, and an achievable one
paragraphs.label: assumption
